Situation1: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I sat in the back row of the conference room, my white coat folded neatly on my lap, listening intently as the speaker explained the latest prescription guidelines. As a pharmacist, I knew how important it was to stay updated—patients depended on me for safe, accurate advice. But as the clock ticked past noon, my mind drifted to the small brass idol I kept at home, the incense I hadn’t lit, the water I hadn’t offered. My family expected me to practice our daily rituals, to honor the gods with devotion and time. Instead, I found myself quietly repeating a short mantra under my breath, hoping it would be enough. The workshop demanded my full attention, but my heart tugged me toward my faith. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each expecting more than I could give. My hands fidgeted with my pen, torn between the duty to my patients and the duty to my beliefs, unsure which voice to answer first.
